INDUSTRIAL ARBITRATION
COURT
ANNUAL REPORT
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: Yesterday the Member for Farrer Park, during the course of the debate on the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's Speech, alleged that the President of the Industrial Arbitration Court had failed to furnish an Annual Report as required by the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1960, and invited me to consider whether such failure could be considered to be an affront to this Assembly.

Column: 2660



    Section 83 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance. 1960, reads as follows:- 
  

  'Annual   83.      The President shall, once in each year, furnish to

reports              the Minister for presentation to the Legislative

                     Assembly a report on the working of the provisions of

                     this Ordinance relating to the Court, to arbitration  

                     and to the registration of collective agreements and

                     of any other provisions of the Ordinance in relation to

                     which he considers it appropriate to report, and in

                     particular the extent to which the objects of the

                     Ordinance have been achieved and any considerations or

                     circumstances which have prevented or hindered the

                     achievement of those objects.'.


The Ordinance does not make it an offence if the President of the Industrial Arbitration Court fails to furnish to the Minister the Report.

    It is clear, however, that the President is under a direct statutory obligation to comply with the provisions of the Ordinance. Nevertheless any failure by hint to do so, of itself, cannot, in my view, he considered to be an affront to this Assembly. It seems to me that the obligation is an obligation on the part of the President to furnish the Report to the Minister, and it is the Minister in turn who is under a responsibility to this Assembly to ensure that the Report is received and presented to this Assembly. In other words, it is the Minister who in the first instance is answerable to the As sembly for the default, if any, of the President.

    If, however, the Minister or any other Member has satisfied himself that there has been a default on the part of the President which, in the Minister's or the Member's view, would warrant the intervention of this Assembly, it is open to the Minister or the Member to move for an Order in the matter and for this Assembly to make the Order if it so thinks fit.

    I am bound to say, however, that it is doubtful whether any such Order could be effective under our present Privileges Ordinance. It is certainly intended that such an Order would be effective under the provisions of the Legislative Assembly (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Bill which has recently been committed to a Select Committee.

COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO
EDUCATION POLICY
(Statement by the Minister for Education)


2.36 p.m.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I understand from the Leader of the House that with the agreement of Opposition Members, the House at the end of the debate on the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's Speech will adjourn to a further sitting next month, may I take this opportunity to say that the Government is prepared to appoint a Commission of Inquiry in accordance with the spirit of the motion tabled by the Member for Anson and the Member for Joo Chiat which reads as follows

    'That this Assembly calls upon the Government to recommend the appointment of a Commission to enquire into the Government's Education Policy, its content and administration in all fields other than vocational and technical education, and to make recommendations.'.

However, on the 19th of December, the Member of Anson wrote further to me suggesting an amendment to the motion by adding the following words:

    'including the six-day week and political activities and machinations in primary and secondary schools, the extent thereof and the persons and organisations responsible therefor.'.

I wish to state, Sir, that Government is prepared to extend the scope of the terms of reference of the proposed Commission of Inquiry to include the six-day week and to investigate into political activities and machinations in schools. But as Government has already agreed to appoint a Commission of Inquiry into the recent examination boycott as proposed by the Member for Anson, the political machinations behind the boycott would be dealt with under this Commission. In view of Government's intention to appoint a Commission of Inquiry along the general lines proposed by the Member for Anson, the exact terms of reference of the Commission of Inquiry will, however, be announced later.

Column: 2662



    My former statement to the Member for Farrer Park during the recent debate on the 1962 Estimates, indicating the early announcement of a revised version of the six-day week for primary schools in 1962, will therefore have to be put in to cold storage and not implemented until the Commission of Inquiry to be set up has completed its findings.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I say that I am indebted to the Minister for taking this question out of the political field? I would like to enquire, Sir, whether it would not be appropriate to have just one Commission instead of two, as I gather he has in mind, and the one Commission can then make an interim report on the political activities and machinations including the troubles in the Chinese middle schools.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is most desirable that the two issues be kept separate and I think it is essential to go deeper into the examination boycott.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, I accept that and I would enquire at this stage whether it would be appropriate to withdraw item 4 from the Order Paper.

    Mr Speaker: There is provision in the Standing Order, which I think the Clerk will indicate to the hon. Member, as to how that should be done.

SPEECH

2.41 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Chor Yeok Eng)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will now continue from where I left off yesterday.

    Yesterday, I talked about certain allegations made by Members of the Opposition and I will deal with some of them.

    During the course of debate on the Yang di- Pertuan Negara's speech, the Opposition Members, especially those in the Barisan Sosialis and the Member for Hong Lim, made certain allegations and accusations which were not quite artistic. They tried to draw a picture of a dragon which was not realistic and certain parts of the picture had to be painted over by other artistic painters. The picture drawn by them was incorrect and very poor indeed. Before we talk about poverty, we have to take the economic situation in Singapore into consideration. If we are faced with an economic situation which cannot meet our requirements, then we will have to look for other avenues to help us tide over it. In recent months, the Members of the Barisan Sosialis have not tried to help us with improving our economic position. On the other hand, they accuse us of having put our economy in a predicament. Because the people are poor, they are unable to buy goods. This contributes to the poor market and products are not easily sold. The blame for some of these things should, to a great extent, be put on the shoulders of the Barisan Sosialis. When merger with the Federation of Malaya is achieved, our products will have a larger market, and this will help to improve our economic situation. This is one of the steps towards this aim. But the Members of the Barisan Sosialis have been trying hard to hinder this move towards merger.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have indicated already that there can be no reference to merger which will excite a debate. The hon. Member is just doing that when he says the Barisan Sosialis are trying to hinder merger. He must not touch on merger in that strain.

Column: 2664



    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I was only mentioning it in passing. I will now continue with another part.

    Mr Speaker: I indicated to the Member for Toa Payoh yesterday that merger must not be referred to in that strain even in passing.

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, now let me reply to the Barisan Sosialis accusations regarding certain situations in the rural areas. They mentioned street lights, water, electricity supplies. On these questions my colleagues already replied yesterday. The Minister for National Development also replied. But I would give a further reply to certain points raised. In the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, it is clearly stated that we will build more agricultural stations next year, and will send more agricultural officers and veterinary officers to carry out services in the rural areas in this respect.

    Let me give an example. We will increase medical services and veterinary services. The services rendered to chickens in the past have been super seded. We are using scientific methods to treat chickens and other domestic animals and reduce their fatality. On the other hand, we are increasing the production of chickens and other domestic animals. This will help the farmers to a certain extent. We will also introduce many kinds of scientific methods to enable the farmers to use these methods to improve their agricultural work and to compete with old methods. There is proof to show that agricultural products have been increased this year. In the past our market was a consumers' market, but nowadays we are able to export our agricultural produce. This is concrete proof of the achievements by the Government.

    Mr Speaker, just now I have been talking about the rearing of chickens. Now I will mention the feeding of pigs in Singapore. These past few years we have been importing pigs of good strain from Europe and America and these have been sold at one-tenth the original cost. This also is to help the farmers in their production. In agricultural experiment situations the chickens hatched every

Column: 2665

month are sold to the farmers at very low prices. In all these fields we have been trying to help the farmers increase their produce by the aid of scientific methods. We will show them how to achieve artificial breeding of domestic animals. This will also help them to a great extent.

    I will now talk about fisheries. On this question, in order to increase their production and reduce their costs, we have been teaching them how to use new fishing boats and fishing implements and we have been supplying certain fishing implements to them. We have conducted for them courses in fishery. In the coming year we will establish more of such schools teaching these courses along the east coast. This is to increase the technique of the fishermen in order to enable them to make a living and be able to compete with others in the business of catching fish. We have also established a mobile motor service station which is to help repair fishing boats on request. Certain officers will proceed to the place where such services are required to repair their motor boats. As to the question of fishermen on certain islands, we have this year already carried out a scheme of distributing goats to them. My colleague will give details of this scheme later on.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, besides agriculture and fishery, we have been providing tractors to the farmers to help increase their production and to reduce labour hands and thus reduce their cost of production. This service has been well received by the farmers. We have also established a mobile teaching institution to teach the farmers how to take care of their lands and how to carry out agricultural and other activities. The aim is to help the farmers increase their production and reduce their cost of production and in this way help them generally.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if all these measures are not directed at helping the farmers in the rural areas, then I cannot understand what can be construed as helping the farmers. I believe everybody will agree with me, that the lot of the farmers cannot be improved just by shouting a few slogans. The Members of the Barisan Sosialis have claimed themselves to be

Column: 2666

revolutionaries. If they are really concerned with the livelihood of the farmers, then let them do something to help the economic development of Singapore and not hamper it.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I will talk about the shortage of arable land, which the Opposition Members have been talking about during these few days. The Gov ernment has already taken steps this year to reclaim lands in the Sungei Poyang area. This project will be completed at the beginning of next year. After completion the land can be put to three uses. First, the land reclaimed can be used to grow vegetables. Secondly, the land reclaimed can be used for fish ponds to increase production. Thirdly, certain lands can provide prawn ponds. All these will help to increase the agricultural products for the needs of Singapore. In this way we will be helping the farmers in their livelihood.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, from the debate, I can come to this conclusion. For the record, I will point out to this House that in the modern political arena, there are two ways in which you take part in political activities. One is where the activities are carried out in accordance with constitutional means to improve the lot of the people, and with the consent of the people. This has been our policy all along. The second way is to create political trouble and damage the economic position of Singapore behind the scenes, thereby hampering the livelihood of the people, to arouse their dissatisfaction, and to urge or excite them to seize political power. This way is adopted by the Barisan Sosialis.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in order to avoid this tragedy occurring in Singapore, I hope the policy statement by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara can be realised and that Singapore will merge with the Federation of Malaya.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, the important question in Singapore today, the question that is in everybody's mind, is the question of unemployment. The Government have indicated that they hoped to ease the unemployment problem through industrial

Column: 2667

expansion, But we are told, Sir, in the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara this is Hansard, Vol. 15, col. 13:

    'Before, however, any significant improvement in the economic and industrial expansion can take place, there must be brought about a situation of political certainty and stability, within which it will be possible for long-term investment of capital to be planned with confidence.'

Sir, His Excellency says, "must be brought about". That indicates that it does not exist today. Sir, may I refer you to an earlier Hansard, Vol. 11, No. 1 of 1st July, 1959, in col. 7. It says here

    'The political stability which is a pre-requisite for expansion and which has been lacking for so long, has been achieved by the election with an overwhelming majority of a Government whose declared policies are clear-cut and unambiguous.'

It says that in 1959, Sir, this stability has been achieved. Again in 1960, Sir, - I refer you to Hansard, Vol. 13, No. 1, col. 5 - it says here in line 9:

    '... Singapore has enjoyed greater political and economic stability than it has known during the last 15 years.'

Sir, we were told in 1959 that stability had been achieved. In 1960 we were enjoying greater stability than was ever known in 15 years. In 1961 we are told that we must go and find that stability; "bring it about". May I ask what has happened to the stability that has already been achieved? Sir, I doubt whether what has been lost can be regained, because when the Government had a powerful majority of 43 against 8, they lost the stability that was already there. Now with a weak 26, it is not likely and not easy that they could regain the stability they have, lost. The trouble is this. There can be no political stability where there is political corruption.

    Sir, non-P.A.P. citizens have chosen non-P.A.P. members to represent them in certain constituencies. They have indicated in no uncertain terms that they have rejected a P.A.P. candidate. They do not want a P.A.P. candidate to represent them. They want somebody else. And what happens? They have a right, Sir - political franchise - to choose whom they like. The Government, if they recognise political franchise, if they

Column: 2668

claim that Singapore has political franchise, must recognise the representative that has been chosen by the people. But not the P.A.P. Government, Sir. They force their representatives on the people. In divisions where the electorate have chosen other than the P.A.P. representatives, they have been forced to accept the leadership from P.A.P. Assemblymen or defeated candidates.

    Sir, I hope you will allow me to quote one more example, Sir, to substantiate my accusation that there is political corruption. When the school at Guillemard was built with public funds, [Laughter] - the Minister laughs; he knows what this is all about because he is guilty of it - that school was built. What happened? When the people went there they did not see the leader that they had chosen. They did not see the person they chose as their representative, but a P.A.P. Assemblyman from a neighbouring constituency was brought into that constituency to act as leader and representative of the people to open that school. Sir, the electorate have indicated whom they want as their leader. Why must they be forced to accept a neighbouring leader to come and lead them? Why must the leader that they have chosen be brushed aside? Sir, I take it this is an attempt to confuse the public into thinking that the P.A.P. Assemblyman is their leader and to make them get used to the idea that the P.A.P. Assemblyman, the P.A.P., is their leader. [Laughter] Sir, the Minister laughs. I tell him this. I have won Mountbatten in a clean fight in the last election, and if the P.A.P. wants Mountbatten, let them fight it in a clean fight in the next election and not rob me of the constituency.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the Member for Mountbatten is perhaps getting too excited. It is not too good for this Chamber. It is not too good for the Speaker. But I would suggest to the Members of the Government Front Benches not to deal with these matters with such frivolity and not to sneer at remarks passed by the Opposition Members.

Column: 2669



    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Sorry, Sir, I take it that not only am I robbed of my constituency, but the constituents are robbed of their leader too. The same attempt has been made. It was not an oversight because this has happened more than once. When the Mountbatten community centre was opened, as has been mentioned before, I was not even invited. In Joo Chiat you knew what happened, Sir, It has been mentioned that a defeated candidate was asked to open that centre.

    How can there be political stability when there is such political corruption? Sir, public funds have been spent not on improving the lot of the people or the State, but to pay P.A.P. cadres, such as Political Secretaries and the People's Association's staff. As I have said before, Sir, the P.A.P. cannot deny this, because the staff have been called upon and told that they either be loyal or be asked to quit. The wishes of the masses have been thoroughly ignored.

    We know that there are 60,000 unemployed, plus the thousands that will be leaving school each year who will be seeking jobs. It looks as if the P.A.P. is unlikely to regain the political stability sought to be brought about. Then what happens? If the solution of unemployment lies in the expansion of industry, if there is no political stability, and it can not be obtained or regained by the P.A.P., I ask them, Sir, for the 60,000 unemployed and the children who leave school, where do they go from there?

    Sir, we have been told in the speech of His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in Hansard, Vol. 15, No. 1, col. 23 (31st October, 1961), that:

    'The problem that is always uppermost in the deliberations of the Government is that of unemployment. This problem has been partially alleviated . . .'.

    It says it has been "partially alleviated". I cannot understand how it has been alleviated when in 1958 we find in statistics that there were about 16,000 unemployed; in 1959, it went up more than double, 36,000; and recently, at the end of 1960, I think, in answer to one of my questions, I think the figure 59,000 was given. Sir, from 16,000 it has gone up to 59,000, and we are told that

Column: 2670

the problem has been alleviated. I remember the P.A.P. did argue that the big number does not mean very much because it was their confidence in the new Government that made them rush to register. The unemployed had always been there, but it was because of their confidence in the new Government that they have come on to the register now. Sir, if you read the Annual Report of the State of Singapore, 1959, page 133, statistics there show that this argument is not very logical unless the unemployed has a funny logic. In 1955, out of 1,381 registrants of unemployment, 368 were given employment, that is about 25 per cent roughly. Then in 1959, out of 3,059 registered, only 313 were given employment, which was less than in 1955. This is only about 10 per cent. Sir, when 25 per cent of those who registered were given employment, the unemployed had no confidence to register, but when only 10 per cent registered, they had all the confidence in the world and 59,000 people rushed to register. Sir, I am sure that is not very logical. But that is the way the Ministers have argued.

    Then, Sir, there has been a lot of talk about industrial expansion. We have been told in the same Hansard as I have read just now, i.e., Vol. 15, No. 1, col. 23, which says the unemployment problem has been partially alleviated; it goes on to say:

    '...by the present boom in the building industry and the gradual materialisation of plans for industrialisation.'

    We are told that plans for industrialisation are materialising and there is a boom in, the building industry. Yet, Sir, if we look in the Malayan statistics, it shows that in the industrial field, manufacturing shows 50,878 employed in 1958 and 42,945 in 1960, both in September, the difference is 7,933, nearly 8,000. 8,000 labourers less employed in manufacturing, but we say that our industry is expanding and the expansion is taking in more unemployed people.

    We are told that there is a building boom when in the same statistics it shows that in the construction section, there is 3,159 less labourers employed.

Column: 2671

Sir, we do not know which to believe the statistics or the statement. Anyway, about unemployment, up to June 1959, there was an unemployment relief scheme which gives temporary relief to the unemployed. There was, I think, in 1959 before June 1,165 who were receiving anything between $3 and $5 with two katties of rice and one katty of sugar to take home to their families. This was abolished immediately the P.A.P. came in, and was substituted by the Work Brigade. Sir, what is the Work Brigade? We all know the meaning of "work", but what is a "brigade"? The Oxford Dictionary gives three meanings: Subdivision of army (and its description), uniformed workers and disciplining and occupying boys. Sir, is our Work Brigade an army? Are they workers or are they delinquents that need to be disciplined? The Government have said, in answer to some attempts to form a union, that they are not workers. They cannot form a union because they are not workers. Then are they a subdivision of any army or are they delinquents meant to be disciplined? We all know what they are, Sir. We have seen what they have been used for, because the P.A.P. has turned an unemployment relief scheme into a Work Brigade spending $7 million not, as stated in this report, to expand opportunities for work. It says here: it has been used to build an army to fight the P.A.P. political battle. It has been organised to form a section of workers who will be depending on the P.A.P. Government for survival and must therefore of necessity be loyal to them. So they thought. We knew what happened. To stand on the roads and cheer the P.A.P. whenever they come to this Chamber the first day of Assembly.

    Sir, in 1959, the P.A.P. came to power with an overwhelming majority - 43 against 8. That shows the people accepted their policies and have given them a full mandate to implement these policies. It shows the people had confidence and trust both in their policies and in the Party. All the people wanted were employment, houses, food and water, peace

Column: 2672

and stability, personal freedom, good education for their children, a just, honest and sincere government. They were promised these, Sir. But the question is: Have these promises been fulfilled? What is the position today? Today there are very many more unemployed than ever before. Sir, the promise of solution of unemployment has been given, but we find there are more unemployed than ever before. Sir, I say that the misery of unemployment and other miseries that have befallen Singapore have been brought by the P.A.P. due to their neglect of duty to the people and the State, due to their arrogance, their mismanagement and their political corruption. In 2½ years they have spent millions of dollars of public funds; they have used almost every Government department to build up a little P.A.P. empire. The people's welfare has been postponed from year to year.

    In the Hansard of Vol. 13, No. 1 (20th July 1960), col. 5, we have been told, Sir, that "The first year of office was one of reorganisation, consolidation and preparation. It was taken up largely with clearing the ground and setting the course for the year of construction ....". But, recently, Sir, the Deputy Prime Minister, when moving the motion of thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, said that between 1959 and 1961, that is the first year, "We first took over the Government, we had to feel our way." he says the first year was "feeling our way". here it says the first year was planning, the second year construction, which means, first year plan, second year action. Here it says the first year was only "feeling our way", second year was for plans for economic development, and only the second half of 1961 marks the beginning of implementation. Well, I hope, Sir, the calendar will not be moved one year back again; it has already been moved one year back; first year planning, second year implementation, and now we hear first year "feeling our way", second year, planning, third year, implementation. I hope something new will not be invented next year.

Column: 2673



    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Third year - acceleration.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Sir, as I have said, they have failed to give employment.

    The next one is housing. Have they succeeded? As you know, Sir, they built practically nothing the first year. When they were exposed here in answer to some of my questions as to the number of houses built, and when it was found that they had built practically nothing, they conveniently at that time blamed the Member for Hong Lim. But now that they have built some, Sir, what do we find? Rents are terribly high; the people cannot afford the rents; and there are lots of houses vacant. Now, Sir, at a time when thousands are on the waiting list, Government keeps the houses vacant. As high as 18 per cent of the one-room, 16 per cent of the two-room and 6 per cent of the three-room premises are vacant, Sir, In all, it comes to a total of 879 units vacant. There are thousands on the waiting list. Not only are the rents high, but they are so ridiculous that certain portions of those houses are naturally vacant and are not likely to be occupied because where they charge $35 per one-room unit - the kitchen, water closet, washing facilities are communal they charge $20 for a room which only has the W.C. as a communal facility, the rest are self-contained. Naturally, nobody wants to take the $35 type of unit. When I ask why, I was told because it was Mr Ong Eng Guan's plan. Sir, we do not care whose plan it was, but the Government must do something.
